text: hi everyone ongoing legal battles here
the uh
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new dope
body album crack a light this is the
latest full-length lp from baltimore mad
men dope body
coming back after their short-lived
breakup several years ago with a
vengeance it seems
dropping yet another lp in one of the
most hellish years
ever 2020 the band fully returned this
past
spring in the midst of lockdowns and
rising death tolls with a record that
reflected the quarantine experience home
body
sure it wasn't the best recording or
production a dope body record has ever
had but that was easily made up for with
quirky
songwriting savage performances and
various sonic experiments across the
track list
the whole thing felt like a grimy weird
mixtape i found
under the beat up cushion of a corduroy
couch covered in popcorn and beer stains
spiritually it also felt like the
successor to the band's last full-length
lp
kunk which was similarly pieced together
from noisy weird and disjointed ideas
i was curious if on future releases
would the band
dig even deeper into this vibe but
crakolite
actually feels like a repeat
of a previous record from the band
a lot of the tracks here just remind me
of the loose wild and chaotic
performances
all over their lifer record from i think
there is a lot of sonic bleed between
all of the harsh
noise rock instrumentation on this one
especially on the heaviest tracks in a
way that feels like an overt nod to
psychedelic rock and psych is something
that it seemed like the band was
dabbling in
a little bit more on homebody anyway
while noise and psych are pretty much
the predominant styles throughout this
new album
there are some pretty clear ties as well
to grunge and garage
as well as post hardcore on certain
tracks now again
even though i think crakolite is very
much a redo for the band in some
respects
that doesn't mean that there aren't
highlights on this thing especially in
the first half
clean and clear is an example where
these crunchy
scuzzy lumbering riffs plod their way
through these odd and strung out verses
it totally sounds like a trip especially
as the band is going into the pre-chorus
and building up with these insane drum
fills and
long ringing guitar leads meanwhile
frontman
andrew laumann's voice just sounds like
he is caught
in the madness the band is creating
there is a super strong
call and response hook on the track
lethargic
then with jerebang we have these very
odd and syncopated yet
spaced out drums and guitar arpeggios
that as they come together it really
reminds me of like an early primus track
or two
it just feels like i don't know if the
jesus lizard was trying to do a primus
cover
but uh with as many psychedelic effects
flying through the mix as possible
daylight features some of the heaviest
most ringing and
crushing riffs on the entire record it
really borders on being punishing
the song has some instantly sticky
qualities to it too
andrew's calls of repent repent
over various instrumental passages on
the track
uh come off as a little unnerving in a
good way
then lulu features some of the most
abrasive and dissonant guitar work on
the entire project
really a return to those clunky
cro-magnon grooves of what i think is
the band's best record
natural history so there's a midpoint
interlude on the project that isn't too
bad but the issue is
after this halfway point the quality
of the songs really seems to drop off
and sure while the band does maintain a
certain level of sonic mayhem
throughout the lp when it drops i mean
it drops
like the sculptor for example where the
quality of the chords and vocals here
is almost night and day as dope body
suddenly shifts into sounding like
a really obscure underground 90s
noise grunge band that never really
quite got off the ground with
this boring demo they seem to be
recording right now
then much of mutant being's run time is
spent on these meandering vocals and
drab noise psych drones that don't
really go anywhere
sure the heavier rift passages are
pretty exhilarating but
that's about it and then the following
more
maybe has the worst lyrics of any dope
body song
ever the writing on this one i think is
seriously half baked in a way i think
the band is making an earnest attempt to
go back to the simplicity of a band like
let's say the stooges but the end result
is falling severely short of the mark
the best highlights on the back end of
this thing ended up being the most
experimental
there's my man with its abstract droning
noisy intro that suddenly shifts into
these driving
righteous punk rock chords and leads
between all of the chaotic delay effects
and
gang vocals it's a really feel good
moment on the project that gets my blood
pumping honestly would have fit as a
closer
but then there's the actual closer on
this thing known unknown where you have
these
synthetic revving tones syncing up with
the drums very tightly is it in
effect i'm not sure either way the track
just gets more and more
blasted and rhythmic as it pushes along
it's genuinely one of the most
experimental cuts on the project and i
just love the
cathartic sensation it brings to the
table i wish more
songs on this thing were as sonically
adventurous as this one
so while this record's track list did
definitely feature some visceral
and infectious moments i also have to
admit this is dope body's
weakest and also most predictable batch
of tracks to date two
especially when you consider one half of
the record is so much better than the
other
so while i guess i did enjoy it overall
hopefully the band brings
stronger material in the future with
more imaginative pastors ahead
feeling a decent two strong six on this
one tran position have you given this
album a listen did you love it did you
hate it
what would you rate it you're the best
